node.statement:
CORRECTED BRANCH SELECTION AND HERGLOTZ PROPERTY (supersedes parent 1.5.3).

The original construction of omega_1 as "the unique w in C^+ with G_p(w) = G_r(z)" is INVALID because, by the corrected Step 1.5.2, ALL n solutions of G_p(w) = G_r(z) lie in C^+ — there is no uniqueness from half-plane separation. This corrective node provides the correct branch selection.

SETUP. The algebraic equation F(z,w) := r'(z)p(w) - p'(w)r(z) = 0 defines an n-sheeted algebraic curve over the z-plane. Equivalently, this is the equation G_r(z) = G_p(w) (away from roots of p and r). By Step 1.5.2, when z in C^+ (upper half-plane), all n sheets w_1(z), ..., w_n(z) lie in C^+.

PART 1: ASYMPTOTIC SELECTION OF THE PRINCIPAL BRANCH. For large |z| with Im(z) > 0:
- G_r(z) = (1/n) sum_i 1/(z - nu_i) ~ 1/z as z -> infinity.
- G_p(w) = (1/n) sum_j 1/(w - lambda_j) ~ 1/w as w -> infinity.
- The equation G_p(w) = G_r(z) ~ 1/z forces w ~ z for the branch where |w| -> infinity.
More precisely, expanding the algebraic equation F(z,w) = 0 for large |z|, exactly one branch satisfies omega_1(z)/z -> 1 as z -> infinity along any ray in C^+. This is the PRINCIPAL BRANCH. The remaining n-1 branches satisfy w_k(z) -> lambda_j (roots of p) as z -> infinity, corresponding to the n-1 finite sheets.

PART 2: LOCAL HOLOMORPHICITY. By the implicit function theorem, F(z,w) = 0 defines omega_1 as a locally holomorphic function of z wherever the partial derivative F_w(z, omega_1(z)) is nonzero. Since F_w(z,w) = r'(z) p'(w) - p''(w) r(z) vanishes at only finitely many points on the algebraic curve (the branch points), omega_1 is holomorphic on C^+ except possibly at finitely many branch points. At these branch points, omega_1 remains continuous (it is constrained to C^+ and cannot jump to a distant sheet) and hence holomorphic by Riemann's removable singularity theorem. Full analysis is in node 1.5.4.

PART 3: HERGLOTZ PROPERTY. Since ALL n branches of the algebraic curve map C^+ into C^+ (by Step 1.5.2), any holomorphic branch — including the principal branch omega_1 — satisfies:
  Im(omega_1(z)) > 0 whenever Im(z) > 0.
This is immediate and does not require uniqueness of the C^+ preimage.

PART 4: SUBORDINATION IDENTITY. By construction, omega_1(z) solves G_p(w) = G_r(z), so:
  G_r(z) = G_p(omega_1(z))
holds identically on C^+ (wherever omega_1 is defined).

PART 5: ANALOGOUS CONSTRUCTION FOR omega_2. Applying the same procedure to G_q in place of G_p yields omega_2: C^+ -> C^+ satisfying G_r(z) = G_q(omega_2(z)) with omega_2(z)/z -> 1 as z -> infinity.

PART 6: SUFFICIENCY FOR THE CHAIN RULE. The chain rule computation (node 1.6) uses only LOCAL data at the real roots nu_k of r: the values omega_1(nu_k), omega_1'(nu_k), omega_1''(nu_k). Near each nu_k (which is a real point generically not a branch point of the algebraic curve), the n branches of F(z,w) = 0 are locally separated (the discriminant is generically nonzero on R), so the principal branch omega_1 is locally well-defined and holomorphic near nu_k. This local data is unambiguous and independent of any global monodromy issues in C^+.

DEPENDENCIES: Step 1.5.2 (all n preimages in C^+).
